OK I'll start it off. For any species S there will be subpopulations of phenotypic variants whose variability is in part heritable. Lets indicate the numbers in each subpopulation as [N] (an array with dimensions of 1..i where i is the number of such populations and Ni is the number of individuals in the N i'th subpopulation. For each Ni there is a Pi corresponding to the probatility of Ni propagating its genes to the next population, a multipication factor Mi which is the number of offspring which will be produced for each Ni reproducting. We can then write out the Ni for the next generation as the product of Ni*Pi*Mi and designate this as Ni,g where g is the generation number. For the zeroth generation we have simply [N] for the second [N2] for the third [N3] etc.and from there its trivial to compute the gene frequecies knowing the specific genetic composition of all the Ns at the beginning. This sucessive probabilistic forward propagation with appropriate gain factors constitues natural selection provided that all the Pi*Mi are not equal.

 The thing to bear in mind is that the trait confers a degree of resitstnce to malaria for heterozygotes. Their RBCs contain both the "defective" hemoglobin AND normal hemoglobin. The RBCs function normally. However the malaria parasite preferentially consumes normal hemoglobin. When infected the RBCs in trait carriers will "sickle" and this results in the infected individals body destroying those cells which are infected in a selective way. Not a bad mechanism for a parasite which otherwise can hide from our immune system. Unfortunately it comes at a cost for heterozygotes!
